[07-Aug-21 10:50 AM] bitcoin_ape#0000
Posting this old message here because the bulk of it is still valid:

```About settling new bases

High temperature, High pressure, High gravity are not possible for anyone in the game right now. The supplies simply dont exist yet. (High pressure coming soon with titanium, but damn will it be expensive)

This leaves normal rocky planets like we are all currently on, or any combination of:

    Gas planet --- AEF
    Low pressure - SEA
    Low gravity -- MGC
    Low temp. ---- INS

With these constraints, Here are my preferred planets and my reasoning for each:

Harmonia -- Easy, local, plenty of food and water, existing corporate trade route due to Tadabe and his coffee situation

KI-840c --- 5 jumps from phobos with magnesium and copper, as well as BRM and some Galerite, Extractors only

WR-681b --- 9 jumps (far) low pressure, lots of copper and some higher tier rare items. Extractor and Collector only.

Etherwind - Tadabe's favorite, best water output available.

Nike ------ Local, low pressure limestone planet. Local market already built.

Allowing for low temperature, we get some really cool shit if we can somehow get our hands on THF -> INS

    KI-401b -- Titanium, Zirconium, Iron
    ZV-639d -- Nitrogen
    AJ-293g -- Fast Fuel```

[20-Sep-21 05:04 PM] spatial_piano#0000
For GAL the options would be ZV-307a, KI-448c, QJ-382c or IY-387a, all of them having their good sides. ZV is basically on top of ANT and doesn't require HSE (but does require TSH). KI-448c is in hermes system and has a better yield. IY-387a has the best yield, and also good amount of FEO, but isn't near anything and requires TSH. QJ-382c has the worst yield out of these, but has a lot of different materials and is in the same system as QJ-382g, so everything would be in one place.

[21-Dec-21 12:31 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
Here is a calculation made on the UFO server that i snagged concerning electronics development

@domicius 

```[RUM] AmAnBear | TRCO
 ‚Äî 
07/13/2021
In order to make 1 BMF and 16 BWS (needed for a COGC) and assuming that your buildings are all running at the same efficiency These are the proportions of buildings that you will need to run the process (standardised to a time in a cleanroom).

ELP    4.006139678
MCA    1.586083397
SCA    0.9518632216
CLR    1
PPF    11.99539524
FS    0.6606998673```


[21-Dec-21 12:34 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
If you want to do vertical production into more advanced electronics, you need to start with a cleanroom and one of the SCA or MCA


[21-Dec-21 12:35 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000

1. https://fio.fnar.net/ Great thing for planning, searching planets. [02-Jan-22 09:56 AM] spatial_piano#0000
Initial investment on IY is higher, but operational costs per unit of HE3 produced are about half of that of Hermes even with the increased maintenance costs (60/HE3 VS 115/HE3 at current prices). Refining of course isn't that great on IY, but even there the cost increase from maintainance is only about 0.45/FF VS refining on Phobos, and about 0.18/FF VS Hermes, which isn't a massive increase.

[20-Feb-22 12:52 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
@deleted-role Sunday strategy update time!


[20-Feb-22 12:53 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
Hello OOG shareholders,

I am here to provide a strategy update for the corporation, but first, we should look back on our accomplishments!

We have met all of our major strategic goals so far on accelerated timelines, AND we have added new members at every step of the way! I have seen the level of activity and base-building accelerate over the past 6 months and I am quite proud of how we have grown and developed.

Our latest accomplishment is to bring on additional farming, food production, and carbon players who rapidly expanded to Harmonia. This has stabilized our supply chain and provided extra headroom for us to expand as a whole. Thank you, and congrats to everyone who took risk on a rapid expansion and to those who helped finance the operations.


[20-Feb-22 12:54 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
Now, the news!

As some of you may have picked up, our largest/oldest OOG members are collaborating to build an FTL ship using mostly OOG-sourced components. Kapusta from AHI corp has joined us on this job to help cover some of the production and planning along with yaro.

This first ship will likely be sold to the highest bidder to float our operations and pay the collaborators fairly, but in the process of building it, we will do our best to duplicate many components so that we can more readily build the next ship for OOG.

{Reactions}

[20-Feb-22 01:07 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
Shipbuilding is very difficult and time-sensitive. It requires a huge range of items, from bulk metal components, full electronics suites including engineer-only and scientist-only production, advanced chemistry, and sourcing of rare materials.

Unfortunately this does not leave much room for help or collaboration on the first ships. At this stage, we are pursuing this as wealthy players who are willing to put up a few million collectively to build the infrastructure.

For those who want to collaborate and get involved ASAP in shipbuilding, please stay tuned to our discussions here and consider possibilities for supplying metals or low-tech production items which feed into the higher tech systems.


[20-Feb-22 01:07 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
I am happy to answer any questions, and will keep you all posted on these exciting developments.

[24-Apr-22 12:25 PM] yang_mills#0000
There is a planet that went unnoticed so far. This is QJ-149c. 2 jumps away from ANT I. It does not have extra requirements for building and offers slightly more ALO than @Deimos . No oxygen though. It could be used as a second aluminium planet for those who don't have area left on @Deimos . One can put some EXT and plenty of SME there. A smart thing would be to add some PP2 producing only BBH (2 AL + 1LST). Else the production of AL is too high which would require to much shipping. With some PP2 part of the AL is consumed locally and on top of that the basic prefabs compress a lot the weight. One would then need to bring in LST. I made a base plan with the PRUNner tool. One can fill the planet with 4 EXT, 9 SME and 4 PP2. The profit per day with the current market prices is 30K AIC. One would have to ship in an average of 120 t per day (DW, RAT, OVE, PWO, EXO, PT, C, O, FLX and LST). One would have to ship out an average of 138 t per day (mainly AL, plus the BBH plus a tiny surplus of ALO). So weight in and weight out are almost balanced. With starting ships this would require a trip there every 4 days on average. But one would better have a ship with a larger cargo.


[24-Apr-22 12:30 PM] yang_mills#0000
Output per day: 46,53 AL net (after subtracting the AL used for BBH) and 13,29 BBH. Plus tiny surplus of 3,94 ALO per day.


[24-Apr-22 12:32 PM] yang_mills#0000
Your second Deimos, but requires a source of O and shipping. So you don't want anything sophisticated high tier there. Just more of the basic AL and BBH stuff.

[24-Apr-22 01:13 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000

[24-Apr-22 01:14 PM] yang_mills#0000
You see, since Phobos has so much more PIOs than SCIs, the total demand for education from all the PIOs is higher that from SCI.


[24-Apr-22 01:14 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
It was rains idea originally to make it electronics.


[24-Apr-22 01:14 PM] yang_mills#0000
Yes.


[24-Apr-22 01:16 PM] yang_mills#0000
So all these low tier pops massively increase the needs for comfort, culture and education, just because of their sheer number.


[24-Apr-22 01:18 PM] yang_mills#0000
That's a problem in the game mechanics. The need fulfilment is calculated for all the population, not by population tier. So to keep SCI happy one has to satisfy the needs generated by the masses of PIOs.


[24-Apr-22 01:19 PM] yang_mills#0000
So on a planet with proportionally less PIOs per scientist, one would need less infrastructure.


[24-Apr-22 01:20 PM] yang_mills#0000
On Phobos the social pyramid has such an unnecessary large base because its an obvious starter planet, with all the new players and their PIOs.


[24-Apr-22 01:21 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000

[24-Apr-22 01:21 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000

[25-Apr-22 10:10 AM] namthorn#0000
it's actually easier to ship the SIO and O to KI-840 rather than shipping the CUO out for processing. A shipload of oxygen lasts 43 runs, whereas a shipload of CUO only lasts 24 runs. shipping the CU back is a bit more demanding but if you're going for something like BCO or SCN you can produce on site and that drastically cuts down your shipping needs for the way back.

[30-Apr-22 04:59 PM] yang_mills#0000
I seriously consider building at some point a base on YK-649b. This planet offers a lot of SIO, twice as much as Phobos. But it's not about the SIO. It's a rocky planet without extra requirements and it's one jump away from Harmonia. The jump is long though. The idea is that one wants to maximise the number of farms on Harmonia, and put the food processors and the incinerators somewhere else. YK-649b could be used just for that. On can fill this planet with 12 HB1, 1 STO, 1 EXT (for the SIO, will free room on Phobos), 12 INC and 16 FP. When fully built up, it consumes more crops than an optimised base on Harmonia could provide. So actually crops from a second Harmonia could also go there. There is already one base on YK-649b. If there are more people who would like to settle there, we could even build a COGC that would provide a food processing (for FP) or resource extraction (for EXT and INC) bonus. It would be a PIO paradise.

[09-May-22 02:44 PM] yang_mills#0000
COF is indeed in high demand. However, the issue is really producing the input, the Caffeinated Beans CAF. It requires HYF and cannot be grown in FRM. And it requires a lot of H2O. So it is up to you to do the math and see if you would be profitable. Producing COF is definitely more challenging than producing C. An other option would be growing HER in FRM and reprocessing it into FIM.

[28-May-22 05:12 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000

[28-May-22 05:32 PM] yang_mills#0000
One can fill the planet with 2 HB1, 6 HBB, 1 STO, 2 EXT (for MGS and CLI), 1 BMP (for MGS->MG), 12 POL (for PG), 2 CHP (for SOI) and 6 INC (for C). Actually producing PG does not require a lot MGS. The bottleneck are the polymers plants POL and the area they take. With less than 1 EXT and 1 BMP one can feed 12 POL. The issue is that it also requires a lot of C (42 per day), and C is heavy and inconvenient to ship. Hence 6 INC. Agri products are easier to ship. With the slowest recipe, 6 INC cover only half the need in C. One could also use the fastest recipe. Then 2 INC cover 50% of the needs. The saved space can be used for one additional EXT and one additional CHP, for more SOI.


[28-May-22 05:34 PM] yang_mills#0000
With this setting, the output is 2K PG per day.


[28-May-22 05:35 PM] namthorn#0000
C is heavy to ship yes, but with a big ship you can feed it fine, if you can make more use of the space running something else.


[28-May-22 05:36 PM] namthorn#0000
I ship about 100-150C in a week making roughly 900 PG a day on griffonstone


[28-May-22 05:40 PM] namthorn#0000
Its also on the route to the ki sector so can assist with shipping in stuff semi-regularly

[08-Jun-22 07:13 AM] insensless72#0000
Ive had a few questions so let me explain my thought process behind the LST wave. While controlling a large portion of the LST supply and reaping the rewards is beneficial to us as a corp, keeping LST prices low on market will benefit us further in the future. keeping LST prices high on the market encourages competition, where as if they sit around 70ish on the market we sell more and there is less incentive for other players to push Nike and create their own rock collection. Now that the LST market is beginning to fall again we have the opportunity to make it less profitable for others. We will be in competition with each other on the market but that is a win win for all of us as we all benefit from each others expansion. Long story short lower prices = less revenue but = more sales in the future and more consistent flow of product since it also = less competition

{Reactions}

[12-Jun-22 02:51 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
@insensless72 
@yang_mills 
@allocater 

It seems like we would benefit from some kind of system to manage fuel on our major planets, stations, trade routes, etc.

I propose a few main points:

1. OOG ships should carry several fuel tanks worth of both fuel types to selected "refuel planets" along common flight routes

2. at least OOG member would maintain fuel inventory + trade offers on these LMs. This potentially allows for a profit margin/gas station type business.

3. OOG pilots maintain full ship refuels at these locations with long date 1 AIC corp buy offers and @somebody mentions


[12-Jun-22 02:52 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000
#1 is meant as an initial push to distribute fuel resources. #2 could be me initially, but I would be willing to give this to anyone in corp really, or at least partial workloads.


[12-Jun-22 02:54 PM] bitcoin_ape#0000

That would reduce our cost per unit of SF by 1.53 (currently 25% of my cost to produce SF; a significantly higher % for YJ) and given the planet is in the same system as Phobos, shipping would be very straightforward.  Anyone seeing something I'm missing?  Is this a good goal as we try to take over the fuel market?  I think the GAL recipe is very important given the volume it allows and the area constraints we have on bases. [16-Jun-22 12:44 PM] insensless72#0000
One could also argue that "shadow markets" are helpful for new players. For instance we offer prices way lower than market value which players could opt to use or flip on the CX whichever is in their best interest.   Corporations hoarding every item of a certain product can be problematic, but would also allow for gaps in the market more players would fill


[16-Jun-22 12:46 PM] churavis#0000
New players need capital and cheap building materials. Old players need large quantities of basic inputs. A corp with both facilitates the trade of both of these in the absence of a formal banking system.


[16-Jun-22 01:09 PM] namthorn#0000
these markets are also essential to get goods TO the CX in the first place. No-one would invest in LST mines on Nike other than what they need for themselves if they had to ship all the excess out all the time.


[16-Jun-22 01:11 PM] namthorn#0000
it would kinda necessitate vertical production lines for heavy goods. No spamming ore driving the price down, no heavy metals.


[16-Jun-22 01:11 PM] churavis#0000
I certainly made good money transporting LST as a new player, it was a good source of extra capital and a way to use up extra shipping capacity.


[16-Jun-22 01:12 PM] namthorn#0000
there's only so much you can support with 2 ships and shipping contracts. not to mention the nightmare of having to receive it all at the CX.


[16-Jun-22 01:12 PM] churavis#0000
I did nuke the LST market once or twice


[16-Jun-22 01:14 PM] churavis#0000
Before I had a good understanding of what good velocity and market saturation is


[16-Jun-22 01:14 PM] namthorn#0000
nightmare of logistical chains too. Instead of taking goods from A -> B and selling at B, you have to go A -> CX -> B with two independent ships


[16-Jun-22 01:15 PM] namthorn#0000
fine for simple stuff. but would really hamper universe growth unless we got a major influx of players, bigger than the steam wave.


[16-Jun-22 01:51 PM] erklein#0000
I did like some of the ideas, or at least the sentiment behind them, i.e. expand more past the starter planets and add buildings that aren‚Äôt solely about resource output. This isn‚Äôt a fully fleshed out thought, but I wonder about implementing some kind of timer on starter worlds where eventually you have to leave to colonize new worlds or bear some sort of huge efficiency penalty


[16-Jun-22 01:55 PM] churavis#0000
I think there should be a gradual reduction in the natural resources of the starter planets or of the number of lower tier workers, so that after several months players have to decide whether to import those resources from far away or transition to a higher tier of industry. That's how it works in the real world, countries start out with the most basic, easiest to start, lowest skill industries and then move on to more complex, lucrative ones as their raw resources run out (or environmental concerns gain precedence) and human capital gets more skilled and more expensive.


[16-Jun-22 02:08 PM] namthorn#0000
you potentially screw over new starters that way. But I agree with the sentiment of offering more lucrative rewards for settling more adverse conditions.


[16-Jun-22 02:09 PM] churavis#0000
You'd just have to move the starters to other worlds


[16-Jun-22 02:12 PM] namthorn#0000
I think you just make the starters worse, a la phobos. and make planets better the further away from the CX they are


[16-Jun-22 02:44 PM] jackinabox86#0000
if the starter planets were worse, it wouldn't be as big a deal if the starting capital was higher


[16-Jun-22 02:45 PM] churavis#0000
We wouldn't need more starting capital if we had banks and loans


[16-Jun-22 02:45 PM] churavis#0000
We wouldn't need any starting capital


[16-Jun-22 02:46 PM] jackinabox86#0000
I probably had a harder start going to Phobos as a constructor at first (heard an old youtube that you could instatrade the CX in system), but it was horribly slow.  Need to be able to either go into higher things faster or more fully vertically integrate early to make returns worth continuing to play (and eventually afford a move out of faction space)


[16-Jun-22 02:49 PM] churavis#0000
So you needed a loan?


[16-Jun-22 02:53 PM] jackinabox86#0000
one random loaned me 25k after a couple weeks, but I just bootstrapped with the starting capital so far.  it takes a long while to expand to a second base (even with the corp price mats I've acquired here).  I think the game would be a bit better off if we had an incentive to move further out paired with an easier starting path to do so


[16-Jun-22 02:59 PM] namthorn#0000
yea starting capital should probably increase over time. Or more easily accessible industries to start e.g. some basic electronics or chemistry at the pioneer tier,


[16-Jun-22 03:02 PM] namthorn#0000
abstracting services would be a decent idea - stuff not required to bootstrap an economy but benefits the economy as a whole later on.


[16-Jun-22 03:34 PM] exeler#0000
The problem with building any system that can benefit new players specifically is that it can also be used by veteran players, or it feels contrived, or there ends up being a huge drop off in productivity/fun once the initial boost wears off. 

I think if the devs wanted to really give new players a place in the economy, it'd be to have  veterans rely on the basic goods produced by new players. That way new players immediately have a place and purpose in the market. 

At least for me, I think that's already the case. I started off as a carbon farmer and it seems like that's a hot commodity. I've never had trouble selling it and there's been enough of a margin on it that I've not really had to think about optimizing much to turn a profit.

I personally don't think there's a problem if late game goods tend to be handled in LM orders rather than being dumped on the CX as long as the volume of basic goods, especially ones new players might be producing, on the CX is good enough to sustain new players.

[10-Aug-22 10:23 AM] yjhasaday#0000
Hi all, I was wondering if there was any interest in updating our corp rate on construction prefabs to offset inflation? I have 5 prefab plants running on Nike so I'm starting to build up stock that I can share with corp members as needed. However some of the current corp prices require me to operate at a loss and I don't think that any corp sale should require someone to lose money (unless there are unique circumstances/agreement). I should point out that I only run 2 con experts (the other 4 spots are needed for fuel experts) but I think there will be others that haven't earned 3+ con experts and may find themselves in a similar situation - such as those with newer bases on Nike. 
The attached screenshot shows the item, current corp rate, and profit/hour of construction prefabs from my spreadsheet. It includes corp discounts on all inputs, standard Nike fees, 2 con experts, and about 90% production line condition. I usually try to put my corp prices at around 20-30 AIC profit per hour to cover any hidden costs (fuel costs for transporting materials, building/ship repairs, unexpected input supply cost spikes, CX trips, etc.). Only the LTA price meets my usual minimum for corp price. 

I think the corp prices I usually set on my products are very reasonable but perhaps I'm the odd one out here so if we want to keep the prices as they are I'm fine with that but since they are pretty old and PrUn has seen a ton of inflation since they were established I thought I would at least bring it up üôÇ It's also understandable if these prices are designed to be below the profit line in an effort to help out newer players that have joined the corp?

https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/870777970367811604/1006945872254353559/unknown.png?ex=6814e36c&is=681391ec&hm=cd4a8c8c831628cc98ad1824da08e871e39deebe9d0bb6f60c75562d7b150ffe&

[10-Aug-22 02:17 PM] exeler#0000
From a new player joining the corp's perspective, the dividend was more than enough to really accelerate my growth. 

I wouldn't mind setting in-corp prices to some ratio of whatever the current market value is. With perhaps inviduals who have more optimized setups able to offer a more stable/lower price. 

If we want to pin a price to something, why not work together to pin it publicly?


[10-Aug-22 02:17 PM] churavis#0000
We want corp prices to be consistent more than anything


[10-Aug-22 02:18 PM] churavis#0000
If we tie them to the market then they become as volatile as the market


[10-Aug-22 02:22 PM] exeler#0000
But then can't we try to contribute to a more stable market?

Like right now ALO is dirt cheap, but AL is kinda expensive. If unstable AL prices are something we want to avoid, why don't we contribute to setting a more stable price point?

If that works, we are able to then reap the benefits of being able to scoop up the materials we need at reasonably stable prices  from outside sources so we don't have to rely on corp members for everything.


[10-Aug-22 03:35 PM] insensless72#0000
The original reason for setting corp prices on bfabs, and C was to help quickly fuel new player growth and establish a solid foundation of players in corp. DLR and I were the primary contributors and were fine operating at a loss as we made money early on and were pretty much 100% vertical, further reducing the hit taken. Corp prices on goods are not and (in my opinion) should never be required, only voluntary. With that being said, bumping up minimums or even throwing out set costs for certain items is probably overdue as most of us are well within the established range at this point


[10-Aug-22 03:45 PM] insensless72#0000
Going off what YJ mentioned here, the prices were also set well before the Steam migration and the average price on market for BSE for example ranged from 650-800, 900max. We originally assumed that the prices would naturally fall back down to their average values, but that has not been the case. As @allocater mentioned, AL is still selling around 450ea where before it could easily be purchased on Deimos for 300 outside of corp. A new evaluation on corp prices is needed


[10-Aug-22 03:54 PM] churavis#0000
It should be noted that new players are generally in need of capital and cheap expansion supplies while older players have capital and expansion supplies but are generally in need of the basic inputs that feed higher tier production chains but  that area/permit limitations do not allow them to make themselves.

My understanding was that a main purpose of the corp was to facilitate old and new players giving each what the other needs. Lower corp prices and loans are a part of this.

{Reactions}
‚òùÔ∏è 

[10-Aug-22 03:58 PM] jackinabox86#0000
one challenge is that corp prices for the basic inputs make it hard for a player producing to them to grow very quickly and provide additional input and overall supply to the corp.  That's very much mitigated by the subsidized bfabs, but I think I think we could help newer players by increasing the corp price for rats or PG, while also making it worthwhile for any player to produce bfabs or things like that.  I look at anything I do at corp price as basically hobbling myself for the good of the corp; that's justified because of the extreme generosity I've benefited from, but if we want supply and demand to work well in-corp, we should be reviewing the corp price on an occasional basis to account for costs/supplies/modest profit


[10-Aug-22 03:58 PM] jackinabox86#0000
and if we want to subsidize newer players further with grants and loans, I think that's an excellent use of the bank.  No reason for capital to sit


[10-Aug-22 04:13 PM] insensless72#0000
Here in the next couple days I will reevaluate my corp costs for b - a fabs along with the other items I sell. I encourage others to do the same. Make sure that once you do, update the corporate sheet. If you notice others selling cheaper or higher than you take that into consideration. I also want to stress that this was a policy enacted to benefit new players so if youre not turning a profit in corp there is nothing preventing you selling on the CX. 

I will recreate and take over the bank of OOG role in case that new players are recruited or existing players need liquid capital for upkeep, expansions, etc

[10-Aug-22 05:32 PM] archielvahr#0000
I constructed my first few buildings by purchasing everything off the CX, and it was pretty slow going at the start. The discount BFABs were a huge bonus, and really kicked things into gear for me. I think raising bfab prices and offering back that income as loans is essentially equivalent, except that often people (including myself) are hesitant to "take on debt", since it adds anxiety about being able to pay it back.... whereas cheap bfabs are simply cheap bfabs. Wealthy OOG members opting into the banking system seems roughly equivalent to opting into our current "low corp price" system.


[10-Aug-22 05:33 PM] archielvahr#0000
I don't really have any sense of how much capital is idle in our distributed "bank account"


[10-Aug-22 05:40 PM] churavis#0000
At a certain point the limiting factor becomes not capital but managerial complexity


[10-Aug-22 06:14 PM] jackinabox86#0000
I get worried that if we have low prices, we‚Äôre dependent on a couple generous producers. That can limit supply and then leave us with a shortage when someone leaves, like the holes were filling after DLR‚Äôs departure. There‚Äôs always going to be a discount and perhaps the possibility of grants, but the way things are structured, a new player could never make a profit in construction joining this corp (which I was when I joined and had to pivot from)


[10-Aug-22 06:21 PM] churavis#0000
But you need to weigh that against the advantages of specialization due to expert stacking and COGC compounding efficiencies together. That specialization is only possible if one has a guaranteed market and the corp provides that.


[10-Aug-22 07:18 PM] jackinabox86#0000
I think that‚Äôs only possible if you have guaranteed inputs or vertical integration, not guaranteed demand. Everything would be much better if we could do recurring custom contracts because you could sell me 1000 PE a week and I could stop thinking about it and focus on my thing. The COGC bonuses actually make it easier for one to compete in the true market because you can produce at scale faster and profit more through volume versus players who aren‚Äôt at a COGC. There is a guaranteed market for pretty much anything one would produce at any scale, and it‚Äôs the CX/global player base. Again, I think recurring contracts priced generously are a great thing to have in corp; I just think that those internal prices should reflect cost and be profitable so we give an incentive to people to participate. If we don‚Äôt price C and RATs decently, we‚Äôll have a harder time getting new players to support longer-term ones through production of those mats.


[10-Aug-22 07:28 PM] churavis#0000
The faster your production the less you spend in consumables and repairs in addition to faster profits due to higher volumes. It also allows you to maximize the use of your land area, which is the biggest limiting factor mid to late game


[10-Aug-22 09:32 PM] exeler#0000
I kinda like the idea of boosting a new player by giving them a 20 day contract to produce X number of things on a new base and just paying a large amount. I think that would skip over the fear of debt a new member might have yet still allow the larger players to help a new player grow. 

For example, instead of "Just ask for a loan to get a new base", we can maybe try "Hey, I need a new C supplier and I'm willing to pay 300k for an order of 500C in 20d". 

New player accepts contract and uses money to start the base and produce the good. If it takes a little longer, the contract can always be extended easily.

@OOG Shareholder The survey link is available here: https://forms.gle/qmbHgSJsrraXnsNd9 A couple notes.  This is anonymous!  If you want to keep it anonymous, but still volunteer to work in a specific area, you can just let me know and I'll put your name, disassociated with your responses, on the list for whoever the leader/s end up being.  I included a number of questions that I personally disagree with, but I wanted to make sure all potential perspectives are offered.  Please don't read into them, or judge me for my silly question on titles.  You do not need to respond to all questions if you don't want to, and if we get many comments in the survey, I'll start separate discord threads for those topics to facilitate further discussions.  Finally, once I have results, presumably early next week, I'll post them for consideration.  Thanks for participating!

{Embed}
https://forms.gle/qmbHgSJsrraXnsNd9
OOG Member Survey (8/22)
Please respond to this survey with as much detail as possible to make the results useful.  Intensity in feeling is as helpful as simply agreeing or disagreeing, as that helps identify priorities and concerns.  Thank you for participating.

[16-Aug-22 09:50 PM] erklein#0000
Putting it out there if any other players want to help me colonize ZV-639D. It's a great N planet that has liquid N meaning you only need to rigs to extract! However, it is also gaseous (AEF) and cold (INS) so there is a definite greater cost to getting set up. I figure that as we expand our agriculture sectors, especially as we get more HYF up, there is going to be a greater need for NS to keep them all running. My personal plans on this planet are to have a base primarily of RIG and CHP, with a couple HYF and FP to simplify upkeep and logistics, so I'm only importing LST and H2O with some other basic supplies. Unfortunately, I haven't expanded much into construction yet so I have limited capacity in personally helping anyone else get started, but I do intend to construct and handle popi upkeep if/as more players arrive on planet. [21-Sep-22 01:23 AM] yjhasaday#0000
@yuen8241 I don't think it's a great idea to start inviting players from outside of Antares space. Moving an entire operation can be very tedious, time consuming, and high effort. One of our main goals with recruitment is to make our member's experiences easy and enjoyable, not demand them to start their whole company from scratch far from the region that they've been getting comfortable in. We have a good group here that is pretty committed to PrUn but not everyone is like us. I fear that requiring relocation from newer players is a recipe for poor player retention. 

However, if you know this person and they are already interested in relocating then send me their company info and lets start a conversation - maybe we can make an exception if the situation is right? Especially if they are into farming!

yeah, you have to delete and readd; I wish you could reorder.  I just ignore the buffer stack though, unless I'm deleting 100+ buffers after using it for weeks


[21-Sep-22 11:08 AM] churavis#0000
I have to empty out the buffer stack every so often, otherwise it will always freeze up whenever I accidentally hit the stack button in an unassigned buffer.

ü•≥ (2) 

[17-Oct-22 11:35 PM] churavis#0000
It's not that there are rules for what industry you can or can't do on whatever planet it's just that you won't get the CoGC efficiency bonus, which is hugely important


[18-Oct-22 12:20 AM] dehzhas#0000
It depends on your bottleneck. For me, there have been a few bottlenecks:
1. Planets that are the next logical/available step given my current logistics
2. The logistics of moving things around
3. Planets that have key resources (H2O, fertility)


[18-Oct-22 12:22 AM] dehzhas#0000
H2O in particular is a huge bottleneck for my FP's. Thus, I tend to optimize rigs on those planets with CoGC extraction for maximum output. My FPs can produce everything I need if I keep them supplied, which is one the the harder parts.


[18-Oct-22 12:23 AM] dehzhas#0000
My manufacturing tends to produce more than enough volume, so CoGC bonus doesn't really do me much good for what I am trying to do.


[18-Oct-22 12:25 AM] dehzhas#0000
CoGC is critical for a fully pipelined steady state, but I'm in hyper-growth stages so building a new base is more valuable than optimizing or re-tooling an old one unless that is the best way to relieve a bottleneck.


[18-Oct-22 12:25 AM] dehzhas#0000
Eventually, yes, I will want to maximize my CoGC bonuses, it just doesn't matter much at the moment given the other options I have.


[18-Oct-22 01:07 AM] yuen8241#0000
COGC is very important to chemical industry and electronics, which greatly affects profits. But for some overproduction, with large capacity consumption productionÔºåthe impact is much smaller.


[18-Oct-22 01:07 AM] yuen8241#0000
However, the biggest advantage of the core planet in ANT region is that COGC can coordinate the division of labor and improve the production capacity. If you like not to consider COGC, in fact, frontier regions such as demeter are more suitable for this way


[18-Oct-22 01:12 AM] yuen8241#0000
There are also some planets with heavy minerals and low consumption. It is very appropriate to make finished products and then transport them to cx. Consumables are usually light, even considering water, so it is advantageous to make full use of COGC.

[20-Oct-22 02:05 PM] exeler#0000
This has been on my to-do list for a little while. 

I currently run a hybrid setup like this on Harmonia just so I don't have to ship the crops off planet.

I've been feeding 12 INC all the HCP and MAI they can take (even with GRN import to burn the fast recipe) and making a little CAF on the side since the HYF are able to really crank out huge volumes of crops. 

The main downside for me is just the initial cost as the MHL are incredibly expensive compared to the rest of the building supplies.

The profit margins on the crops are worse because you need more H2O per crop you produce, as well as the added NS, but the issue with crops has never been the margins. The area cost for a FRM and the long production times are the biggest drawback to farming for me, and HYF solves both of those problems.

After I get my NS base set up, I wouldn't mind risking setting up a 100% HYF base somewhere. I would want to make sure that there's an in-corp use for the volume of crops that the base produces though. 

I'm guessing that there's plenty of INC that are currently just burning GRN that would greatly benefit from large quantities of readily available HCP and MAI.

[31-Oct-22 08:52 PM] yuen8241#0000
If you simply use one fp planet to produce dw to consume etherwind's water, you can switch back and forth between the two production formulas to maximize profits.


[31-Oct-22 08:55 PM] yuen8241#0000
But generally speaking, there is only one H2O planet for each of us, and there are still many places where H2O is needed, so it is better to use Pg formula to save water.  If you are willing to buy H2O to produce more DW, that's fine, but in this case you can even build a second FP planet.

I wanted to pause my production (because I ran out of AMM and knew it would take a few days to replace it). I hid the consumables in a warehouse, but production continued even after (what I incorrectly presumed was the start of the cycle timer) the Norwick Population Report 16 hours ago.


[08-Nov-22 12:03 PM] Deleted User#0000
So I kept checking back to see what would happen. Finally, just now, the workforce consumables went empty for some items:

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/870777970367811604/1039601043513811004/image.png?ex=681508eb&is=6813b76b&hm=36b6e929af7350a981104972804dd895d86ee214b60f3ce8edbd2415341d1a74&


[08-Nov-22 12:04 PM] Deleted User#0000
Two interesting things: the timer on the KOM is not in sync with the others, and also the REP seems to continue using something from the prior day (presumably 0.8 unit remainder.


[08-Nov-22 12:06 PM] Deleted User#0000
I also learned something else, when I tried this before.. if you add the consumables back, within the same 24 hour cycle, then the entire amount will be consumed (even though there was only 12 hours left of the cycle).


[08-Nov-22 12:07 PM] Deleted User#0000
I like learning about the game mechanics, and I thought I would share. ü§ì


[08-Nov-22 12:14 PM] archielvahr#0000
Hmm! interesting that it sucks up the entire cycle!


[08-Nov-22 12:14 PM] churavis#0000
Does it suck up the entire cycle or just start a new one?


[08-Nov-22 12:22 PM] Deleted User#0000
Going to test it, by consuming 1 RAT and telling you what it says, tomorrow üß™ üî¨

{Reactions}
üêÄ 

[08-Nov-22 12:26 PM] churavis#0000
My understanding is that a POPR, new building, getting new consumables after a shortage or any other event that affects the rate of consumption will reset your consumption cycle to be the time of day of that event.

‚òùÔ∏è (2) 

[08-Nov-22 05:16 PM] dehzhas#0000
For my part, I think it is only really worth trying to stop scalping on high volume essentials like DW, RAT, OVE and others that the region needs to keep going strong. It would be nice to stop scalping on bfabs, but you can wait on those if you have to. Basic consumables will quickly keep new players from being liquid


[08-Nov-22 05:19 PM] dehzhas#0000
Prices generally seem on the rise as demand is high. Gives scalpers the advantage. I think the most effective mitigation is to keep the essentials readily available.


[08-Nov-22 05:31 PM] domicius#0000
It's one way for a rich person to get richer. I have no strong feelings about it though.


[08-Nov-22 05:46 PM] archielvahr#0000
A scalper spent a bunch of money to raise the price of goods, every good you sell at the raised price is bonus profit you didn't "pay for" (in the form if buying to inflate prices)


[08-Nov-22 06:10 PM] yuen8241#0000
In a sense, fabs scalpers will increase the number of nike bases. People who can't stand the high price of fabs will come to nike to build a base to produce their own products.


[08-Nov-22 06:23 PM] dehzhas#0000
Scalping will tend to increase prices and encourage people to build those bases. Scalping is a short term move when there is a supply shortage.


[08-Nov-22 06:23 PM] dehzhas#0000
Scalping only works long term if you can prevent the supply from improving. It might work longer in this game because the supply might not be able to keep up with demand for a while.


[08-Nov-22 06:25 PM] yuen8241#0000
Fabs is different. It is generally used for expansion. If the cost is too high, it can be postponed or even cancelled. But consumables can't. .


[08-Nov-22 06:26 PM] mrtcsmith#0000
New players may be less likely to tolerate high fab prices rather than slightly higher consumables as the feedback cycle of expanding their base is longer and harder to achieve making the start of the game even more tedious.


[08-Nov-22 06:28 PM] exeler#0000
And one solution for a new player is just to quit the game, which sucks.


[08-Nov-22 06:28 PM] yuen8241#0000
For new players, fabs is the biggest expense. If ANT's fabs is expensive, they can go to other cx to buy it. Considering that the price difference is so large, it is appropriate, and the initial ship is enough to bring them back.


[08-Nov-22 06:29 PM] yuen8241#0000
Goods with high weight, high consumption and high frequency are generally not easy to buy from other cx.


[08-Nov-22 06:30 PM] yuen8241#0000
The most typical ones are C and metal.


[08-Nov-22 06:31 PM] mrtcsmith#0000
A really new 1st or 2nd week player won't do that though, not after being told to sell half their fuel and seeing it will take a number of days to get there and back. They also don't have the capital to make saving a few hundred credits on a handful of bfabs to cover the cost of flying to another CX and back worth it.


[08-Nov-22 06:32 PM] mrtcsmith#0000
Cheaper bfabs encourage growth and that will mean older players can sell more other higher tier products to newer players


[08-Nov-22 06:33 PM] yuen8241#0000
The current situation is that the total differnce price is about 100,000, and generally, the cross-cx trade of the initial ship simply can't earn so much.


[08-Nov-22 06:34 PM] yuen8241#0000
As a matter of fact, a WBC ship can't earn so much unless it buys very expensive goods.


[08-Nov-22 09:03 PM] Deleted User#0000

[09-Nov-22 12:29 AM] dehzhas#0000
Thinking this through a bit more, basically, the active scalping that is taking place is a sign that the materials being scalped are priced too low.


[09-Nov-22 12:29 AM] churavis#0000
Only according to one person


[09-Nov-22 12:30 AM] dehzhas#0000
If people didn't agree, they wouldn't buy at the higher price.


[09-Nov-22 12:30 AM] churavis#0000
If people don't agree then they sell it for less, which is exactly what happened for most the items


[09-Nov-22 12:31 AM] dehzhas#0000
That is, if the materials are already near the high end of their actual value, the scalper can't make money. If they are making money, then people are willing to pay that price at some level.


[09-Nov-22 12:32 AM] dehzhas#0000
Exactly, people are willing to sell for less, but in theory, the scalper could just swoop in and buy those goods too, limited only by capital.


[09-Nov-22 12:34 AM] dehzhas#0000
To make money, the scalper has to be able to sell though. One of the DW scalpers has been scalping PG. People are still paying for it though because the demand is high and the price hasn't made it a negative ROI.


[09-Nov-22 12:46 AM] mrtcsmith#0000
Basically bfabs are like petrol or drugs, demand is largely inelastic as the price rises because there are no alternatives


[09-Nov-22 12:47 AM] churavis#0000

[22-Dec-22 02:08 AM] xenoxerarch#0000
Ah, that explains it.


[22-Dec-22 02:09 AM] xenoxerarch#0000
sounds dumb but I always try and leave at least a single unit up on the CX as a visual baseline to tease people into aligning their sales with that number. Its a little mind trick and I don't know how much it actually works, but I've noted having zero stock directly translates to inflated pricing

{Reactions}
üëÜ 

[22-Dec-22 02:10 AM] xenoxerarch#0000
Only works for low fluidity stock though. Anything that buys/sells fast won't benefit from such silliness.


[22-Dec-22 02:10 AM] xenoxerarch#0000
On the other hand, I'll buy out a little more than necessary if it means wiping out a stock I'd like to see increase in price üòâ

Question. Has anyone done the math to see how much of what goods we're all producing; how much is sold intra-corp; how much we buy from extra-corp sources; and how much goes to open market?


[28-Dec-22 04:36 AM] xenoxerarch#0000
Might be optimal to find out what industries we've a solid chokehold on, and which are still open/viable for expansion - or otherwise low market share - thus viable to push out foreign non-corp competitors who ship in for extra profit from outside markets.


[28-Dec-22 04:38 AM] xenoxerarch#0000
Especially for higher cost/volume goods we don't produce domestically, and rely on.


[28-Dec-22 05:58 AM] xenoxerarch#0000

Something that isn't shown anywhere, and we'd need to manually ask folks in order to know? [28-Dec-22 08:46 AM] archielvahr#0000
Unfortunately governors get very very little information like that. We really only know how much tax income all our planets put together make. We don't have a breakdown planet-by-planet. WE don't have a breakdown of LM fees vs. production fees vs. warehouse fees. You can get decent estimates of some of those by doing things like checking the total number of rented warehouses, or looking at total planetary employment

{Reactions}
üò≠ 

[28-Dec-22 08:46 AM] archielvahr#0000
The devs are aware of the issues and it's somewhere on the todo list.

[01-Feb-23 06:52 PM] yuen8241#0000

[01-Feb-23 11:34 PM] domicius#0000
MMs are also a way of making sure that some complicated goods remain expensive, by setting a minimum floor. However they need to be more dynamic by eg responding to how many players have SE in the game.


[01-Feb-23 11:35 PM] domicius#0000
Agreed on new players. We're all here to offer each other a competitive source of goods and the ability to work together, rather than just an internal market.


[02-Feb-23 12:19 AM] evov#0000
I'm not looking for "corp" prices, discounted goods, loans or favors. To be honest, I'm wary of most internal markets or walled gardens as I feel like they can end up being more restrictive than beneficial in the long run. I buy some things, I sell some things, and I feel like there's often a net benefit to be found when interacting with people directly. If it's helpful to anyone, I'll work on putting together a more detailed list of my production capacities in case anyone might have a need of something I can provide.


[02-Feb-23 12:28 AM] churavis#0000
Late game players are constrained by area and managerial capacity but have plenty of capital. Early game players are constrained by capital but have plenty of excess area and managerial capacity. Corp prices, loans, grants and sponsored bases allow early and late game players to trade what the have in abundance for what they are constrained by.

You play how you want but our system is extremely effective at optimizing strengths and weaknesses for maximum growth.


[02-Feb-23 02:33 AM] allocater#0000
Don't be afraid of adjusting your offers to the market prices. For example C is now ~500. Discounts offers are entirely voluntary. Benefit is volume, regularity and simplicity.

Ultimately, I don't think it's worth the hassle, especially if you're planning on creating HQs for each governor (or even some of them). Governorships can be fluid, and change frequently. [16-Feb-23 09:51 PM] yuen8241#0000
So the upstream products I am talking about are Rfabs and consumables. These things are all rising in price because of EDC. If you don't participate in EDC or these related industries, your profits will be eroded by the inflation they bring.


[16-Feb-23 09:52 PM] yuen8241#0000

[17-Feb-23 02:06 AM] allocater#0000
each EDC base is printing ~40 million over its lifetime (80-100d). That money is distributed among the FIM, R-fab industry and the base operator. Atm, FIM takes 30%, R-fabs take 20%, and the EDC base operator takes 50%. A tax of 1440 would take about 5%.


[17-Feb-23 02:09 AM] allocater#0000
as R-fabs and FIM increase they will take more of the pie, but if one person operates all himself, they always will keep all of the 40mil pie


[17-Feb-23 02:14 AM] yuen8241#0000
The difference between MM products and other products is that it will generate new money, which will lead to the devaluation of the money of non-MM products producers and suffer losses under the new wealth distribution pattern.


[17-Feb-23 02:15 AM] yuen8241#0000
MM is the printing press, and whoever has mastered the faucet will be richer.


[17-Feb-23 02:16 AM] yuen8241#0000

[13-Jun-23 02:42 PM] archielvahr#0000
The other issue is they have that Steam Review -> Discord plugin going, so they stress hard about every negative review they get. All the negative reviews are players with <2 hours bouncing off the game... and it's listed as a free game on steam, so it's destined to have bad reviews, because it gets a ton of uninvested players who try it just because it's free.


[13-Jun-23 02:43 PM] archielvahr#0000
So they see those negative new player reviews... and know they shouldn't compromise the vision of it as a cerebral game... and they end up compromising with weird newbie friendly features, or endless tutorial rewrites (eve's approach to the "new player experience") has run through this for decades too


[13-Jun-23 02:50 PM] mrtcsmith#0000

[25-Aug-23 12:38 PM] churavis#0000
I propose the following nicknames for ships for the sake of brevity and clarity:

*Hauler: a ship with a WCB 3k ton/1k volume capacity and low tier engine (QCR, RCT, ENG, FSE)

*Carrier: a ship with an LCB 2k ton/2k volume capacity and low tier engine (QCR, RCT, ENG, FSE)

*Tanker: a ship with a VCB 1k ton/3k volume capacity and low tier engine (QCR, RCT, ENG, FSE)

*Puddlejumper: any ship with only slower than light capability

*Lifter: a ship with 500 ton/ 500 volume cargo bay or greater that also has high tier engines(AEN, HTE, HPR, HYR) high tier plates(RHP, HHP, AHP) and gravity seats of either kind

*Yacht: a ship with 250 ton/ 250 volume cargo bay or less that also has high tier engines(AEN, HTE, HPR, HYR) high tier plates(RHP, HHP, AHP) and gravity seats of either kind

{Reactions}
üëç

[26-Aug-23 04:42 PM] parisinspringtime#0000
I'm going to disagree: "clippers" were really little yachts that carried very small, very high-value cargo at mast-break speeds. "Yachts" should be renamed "clippers".
"Yachts" are what rich douchebags sail to only move their fat lards around.
I also think "Carriers" should be renamed "Cathedral" ships, but that's a personal preference (from obvious reference).
"Lifters" could be named "galleons", since they were the big-cargo _and_ fast ships of their time.


[26-Aug-23 04:43 PM] parisinspringtime#0000
Though "cruiser" would also work, since they are big and fast (they are military ships though, if that matters).


[28-Aug-23 01:05 PM] churavis#0000
I was thinking about the names over the weekend and decided I liked Higgsy' idea of using an adjective to describe the engine tier and the noun to indicate the cargo bay size. I wanted the adjective to be single syllable and the noun to be a two syllable word ending in '-er'. This is what I came up with:


[28-Aug-23 01:05 PM] churavis#0000

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/870777970367811604/1145781200846344304/Screenshot_20230828-1204232.png?ex=68150965&is=6813b7e5&hm=a555cea81f943aeca544fb0b6111de876a1e73775126eecd62fe5bbe43d57d7a&


[28-Aug-23 02:06 PM] exeler#0000
Could break out the engine types a bit more. 

Stock - Tier 1 - RCT, ENG
Improved - Tier 2 - QCR, FSE
Premium - Tier 3 - (whatever is next)
Lux - Tier 4 - ...

Then an STL only ship could have a prefix of Cab (or whatever else we decide) so you could have a Stock Clipper, but also a Cab Stock Clipper

The nice thing about the different pieces of the naming convention having specific purposes is that you could leave out any of the descriptive words if they're not important. 

"I'll send my Hauler on over there" means "I'll send my 3k/1k ship over there" or "I've got a Cab in that system for that" is "I've got an STL only ship in that system for that".  Specific phrases that communicate specific information are easy to craft and consume naturally.


[28-Aug-23 02:21 PM] churavis#0000
There is a cost to more specificity, in that it's harder to remember and use, especially for newbies. Do the benefits of that greater level of specificity justify the cost?

In addition, it's not that crazy to imagine someone putting an RCT with an FSE, what would you call it then? You wouldn't put it with an HYR, on the other hand.

Most importantly, I could not, for the life of me, find a synonym for conventional that was one syllable besides stock, even lux and cab are pushing it.


[28-Aug-23 02:25 PM] churavis#0000
Also, yes, I expect that people will not always use the both names, in which case you can assume it's whatever version is most common, e.g. just saying 'carrier' would mean a stock carrier and just saying 'cab' would mean a cab clipper.


[28-Aug-23 06:25 PM] exeler#0000
I mean for shipping contracts if someone says they have a carrier, I'd just not assume any other specs. All I really care about is that it's a 2k/2k. 

I think for basically all day to day uses people will just use the shipping capacity of the ship to identify their ships. So just carrier, hauler, tanker, clipper, etc. 

The only time the other parts are important is when someone is requesting the parts to build a ship. I think having a small set of extra quantifiers to say what "tier" of ship they want gives us some simple vocabulary to talk about them. Especially since the production chains for the different tiers of engine can be pretty different. 

We may have tons of parts laying around for standard ships, but have a long waiting list for the lux stuff.

I think to go along with what you said, having too many of these terms could be too complex to the point of being unusable. So I like the idea of having just a few terms like you've enumerated here. 

For someone building a mismatched ship that uses different tires of engines or doesn't fit one of the standard categories, we'll just have to revert to using specific item names for things.

{Reactions}
üëç 

[28-Aug-23 06:32 PM] churavis#0000
If no one else has any input or objections, I'll introduce the table above to UFO and see what the general public thinks. If we've done our job well, striking the right balance between simplicity and utility, intuitiveness and brevity, then it should catch on easily and organically

{Reactions}
üëç

The depreciation is included in the per unit costs I listed. So profits will be slim, but definitely do some more in depth analysis


[05-Sep-23 08:33 PM] pateirn#0000
Any ideas on the most effecient planets/shipping?


[05-Sep-23 10:34 PM] archielvahr#0000
A while ago we had floated a HYF planet somewhere near ISA


[05-Sep-23 10:35 PM] archielvahr#0000
I don't do C production personally, but whatever you grow in a HYF takes pressure of FRMs


[05-Sep-23 11:33 PM] exeler#0000
With a single HYF base you can fuel a ton of INC. 

My ideal plan would be to find a way to get shipping to balance out. If I can fly H2O in, swap for crops, hop over a planet, drop the crops and swap for C, then fly back out that would be sweet.


[05-Sep-23 11:37 PM] fremen45#0000
It depends on what recipe you are using. To produce the most C you would need to run the 8 hour recipe which is 1000 space of farming to support.


[06-Sep-23 12:22 AM] exeler#0000
Stacking the fast recipe with HYF goods brings the cost per C up quite a bit. 

With HYF you're already trading a higher cost per crop in exchange for making a ton more of them. 

So running the fast recipe on already expensive crops makes for very expensive C. 

I usually run the HCP+GRN and HCP+MAI recipes in the INC with cheap GRN and MAI from a FRM base.


[06-Sep-23 06:54 AM] pateirn#0000
Okay, the cost is what I never really looked at. It is significantly cheaper to do GRN and MAI in a FRM? Then just run HYF on all HCP?


[06-Sep-23 06:58 AM] melon164#0000
FRMs have better ROI (higher profit per $ invested), but HYFs are denser (higher profit per base area unit invested)


[06-Sep-23 06:59 AM] melon164#0000
So for your first or second base, where the permit is free, FRMs are better.  For your 25th base where the permit costs you 50M, HYFs are better


[06-Sep-23 06:59 AM] melon164#0000
There are also limited fertile planets, but you can put HYFs anywhere


[06-Sep-23 07:53 AM] pateirn#0000
Okay that makes perfect sense. I have HYF on Harm right now, was planning FRM on Demeter.


[06-Sep-23 11:56 AM] exeler#0000
Yeah, I think FRM has one of the highest ROI based on input cost. The limiting factor is time and places to build FRM. 

FRM take up a ton of space so you can't build a ton of them. Then they work slow, so you don't get a super amazing throughout. 

HYF are more expensive to build, cost more to run, but produce more and take up less space. So HCP that comes from a FRM is a lot cheaper to make, but you're limited by how much you can make. 

I want to find a few planets with no resources (or at least no useful concentrations of them) on them to turn into HYF agriculture worlds so that the fertile agriculture world's can be used for FRM. 

Putting HYF on a fertile world just to take advantage of the agriculture COGC is a waste of the area that could've been using the planet's fertility.

Summary:

Options near Etherwind
    Need to look!

Options near Ice Station Alpha
* ZV-639 b
    1 jump from ISA and CX- TSH only
* SE-110 same system as ISA.
    SE-110e -> AEF + INS
    SE-110b/d -> INS + SEA
    
Options near Nascent:
* YK-005 a
    One jump from Nascent, towards Harmonia.
    TSH only
* IY-816
    One jump away from Nascent, away from CX
    IY-816d has EXT based Water, SEA + INS, probably better to import from ISA/Etherwind
    IY-816e INS only, for HYFs
    Has puddlejumping opportunities
* QJ-149A for HYFs.
    Same system as Nascent
    TSH only
    
Threats: SE-866e (get murdered by Hern)
    SE-648a (get stabbed by Paris)
    
Cost guide for 20 HYF planet:
SEA: $23k
AEF: $324k
INS: $468k
TSH: $660k

Shipping guide:

[09-Sep-23 12:53 PM] archielvahr#0000
```Orbital Structures
Allows to build space stations in orbit around planets, allowing to use ships for transport that do not require the ability to land on planetary surfaces or fly within atmospheres.```

[13-Sep-23 07:35 PM] archielvahr#0000
Actually everything in QJ-149 is about the same. The gas giants clock in at 2,480,000 AIC per HYF base. so maybe that was a poor threshold. There is probably enough price/availablity variability that they are all about equal in-system. There's a case for putting it closer to the water tap than the INCs, but the incs seem a bit more popular.
`    QJ-149a         HYF Base Cost: 2368k      High Temp (TSH), `
or
`QJ-149g/f         HYF Base Cost: 2480k      Low Temp (INS), Gas (AEF),`

LS-231c/d is a good choice if we are by etherwind. It's on the way if you're coming from etherwind to Nascent. 
`LS-231c         HYF Base Cost: 1960k      High Press (HSE),`

Near ISA, in system at SE-110b is an okay choice 
`SE-110b         HYF Base Cost: 2179k      Low Temp (INS), Low Press (SEA), `

[09-Oct-23 11:23 AM] archielvahr#0000

[09-Oct-23 01:31 PM] archielvahr#0000

[09-Oct-23 01:46 PM] hernanduer#0000
it's a multiplicative 25%, so with experts it can actually be a good bit more


[09-Oct-23 01:47 PM] mrsmith33#0000
You get 160.5% total


[09-Oct-23 01:47 PM] mrsmith33#0000

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/870777970367811604/1161012076597223424/image.png?ex=68151341&is=6813c1c1&hm=08f258706c356cbaa47c531bf2589c4cfa9ab936f7497f9ee62debc40a2dd0e7&


[09-Oct-23 01:47 PM] hernanduer#0000
it's 1 * 1.25 * 1.28 rather than 1 * (1 + .25 + .28)


[09-Oct-23 01:48 PM] hernanduer#0000
right so it's 160 - 128=32%

{Reactions}
üíØ 

[09-Oct-23 02:43 PM] archielvahr#0000
And in cases where upkeep costs are high, it can be a big deal:
At 100% efficiency, an AML takes 14h24m to make 1 W from 5 BTS.
During that time your workforce will consume 4213 AIC and the AML will degrade 3690 AIC. BTS is a static cost (assume you bought it from me for 350/u: 1750 total).

That's 9653 AIC spent per W. 

 Let's pretend you sell it for 11k, that's ~1400 AIC in profit.

But if you pick a good COGC and experts, at 160% efficiency:
Degradation: $2299
Workforce: $2625
Input BTS: $1750 (unchanged)

That's 6674 AIC per W. Sell at 11k and your profit is $4300 per W }
(and you make it faster too!) 

So that's like a 6 fold profit on the AML per day once you calculate in the time savings too. 

That's why I really really try to align with COGCs, especially where buildings and workforce are expensive


[13-Oct-23 04:46 AM] parisinspringtime#0000
Sorry to be late to the party, but following the COGC is like having an extra 1/4 permit on the base, without having to pay for consumables, degradation or repairs. Only you can know if that extra production & cost saving is worth it for you.

Does feeding the consumables drive unemployement up?


[31-Oct-23 04:00 AM] domicius#0000
I was gonna stop sticking my DEC into it after I finished the current load. The rest is just cheap stuff.


[31-Oct-23 04:00 AM] domicius#0000
Replies


[31-Oct-23 04:08 AM] parisinspringtime#0000
Yes, unemployed POPs will keep going up if you keep feeding them. I find a balance of around 5-10% unemployed is a good target.
Also, high unemployed PIOs & SETs will make growing TECH & ENG harder, since you first have to feed the unemployed of the lower classes before the upper classes will get fed and grow. This isn't an issue right now but could be in the future.


[31-Oct-23 06:43 AM] domicius#0000
OK. I'll be less generous.

[31-Oct-23 11:58 AM] hernanduer#0000
here's all the resources I found that are critical for colony starting

ALO - NG-246b - 30.61 - HSE + INS (10th highest in universe)
NE - YV-391f - 9.58 - INS
AR - YV-391f - 7.81 - INS
FEO - QF-564d - 46.91 - SEA + INS
H2O (l) - NG-848d - 40.42 - HSE
N - NG-246g - 52.01 - INS (the highest in universe)
HAL - NG-164d - 19.1 - SEA + INS
LST - NG-848b - 47.24 - TSH
TIO - RV-276a - 20.43 - HSE + TSH (9th highest in universe)
SIO - QF-930c - 50.04 - none
CUO - NG-574b - 20.60 - SEA
H - QF-564e - 41.64 - INS (5th highest)

[15-Dec-23 07:06 PM] archielvahr#0000
Oh to fill in @cleavingambiguity, my vague plan for colonizing OS-099 is based on the fact that it's the only system with 3 cheaply habitable planets (MCG or SEA only) in the whole universe. It's 4 jumps from GM-498 which is a really good water planet- one of the best in the game, although it has some expensive materials. Downside is that there isn't much for great materials in the region, or something to do with them. No fertility nearby, so crops would be in HYFs. 

So... that leaves you with your choice of 3x COGCs in one system. Maybe the best you can do is make 3 electronics bases and farm EDC/IDC there, since that's a minimal shipping thing. But you'd be starting the POPI from scratch, so it's probably better to do that in already colonized space, just spread out. 

Trying hard to find any plausable case for going out there

[01-Jan-24 11:05 PM] archielvahr#0000
An update to my ongoing OS-099 work. I made my planet search python script mark the top 5 locations for each resource type. It takes into account the penalty for Mineral water vs. liquid water, for example. It doesn't take into account the habitability of those planets though.


[01-Jan-24 11:07 PM] archielvahr#0000
It turns out that there are some pretty good resources available around OS-099. In particular, one of the best O planets, one of the best H2O planets, and really good sources for TIO, LST, ALO, HE, FEo, and LIO.

[01-Jan-24 11:25 PM] archielvahr#0000
Anyway, as far as growing an industry in OS-099... there is H2O, so you _could_ make carbon down there and smelt some highly available ores. I don't think that really gets you too far since H2O -> HYFs -> INCs -> SMEs is 4 planets already and then you gotta ship the metal back.. so that's a crappy chain to pursue.  Having better ALO/FEO/LST than Nike/Vulcan/Deimos doesn't really buy you that much if it's that far away. 

Chemistry would be a better chain to move down there, more value, less shipping back and forth... more value in having many planets. But the gasses aren't really there.

So that leaves the idea of putting 3 software farms on OS-099


[01-Jan-24 11:25 PM] archielvahr#0000
This is definitely still a solution looking for a problem üòÑ

[23-Jan-24 01:04 PM] churavis#0000
Can we put together a list of recruitment standards?


[23-Jan-24 01:30 PM] archielvahr#0000
I've been thinking we should have some for a while. I think in my views, I mostly want someone who communicates regularly and coherently and are involved in the corp. At least 2/3rds of their bases in ANT space or something similar..? 

I've only ever invited pro/basic users. I think that's a good requirement. 

Giving out my ANT development grants has been a nice way to strike up conversations and see if people are on a good track before considering sending them an invite. 

I often ask about their plans or goals, not because it's important that they have any specific goal, but it's nice if they have some coherent thinking on the topic- assuming they've been playing long enough to understand the game. If they are gonna stick around for more than a month or two, they should have an interest in working together on ship parts, governing, finance / loans / market making, or some kind of personal project. 

Since the content has been pretty slow from the devs, I think a lot of us are in semi-retirement. Unfortunately that turns into a slow ship into totally inactive and people don't leave the corp when they quit. I'm not really upset about it cause it's sort of inevitable and understandable. But it's hard to track how many members are inactive so I don't know if we should be recruiting.


[23-Jan-24 01:34 PM] archielvahr#0000
Oh, the other thing I always do is check their message history in the Prosperous Universe and UFO discords, you can get a good sense of someone from that often


[23-Jan-24 01:35 PM] archielvahr#0000
If they are active in there, they will probably be active in the corp

{Reactions}

[09-Feb-24 11:33 AM] archielvahr#0000
Okay, the channel cleanup is complete. 
The two #public-welcome and #public-general are visible to guests. All of the recruitment and general rules are in public-welcome. The #shareholders-welcome  contains the more internal information, including things trial members will need to know. 

Everything else is restricted to shareholders and trial members (there's nothing trial members can't see). Any Governor can post to the welcome channels to update rules, but generally it's a read-only channel. 

If everything looks goods, @allocater  can remove/archive #rules-faq #welcome #ship-status  and #oog-c-suite. Those I don't have permission to touch I guess.  (I think if you assign me the Mod role, I will be able to)

[10-Mar-24 12:40 AM] Deleted User#0000
why do you need supporter level for an activity tracker? and what's with the section after creation date?


[10-Mar-24 12:41 AM] Deleted User#0000
just curious


[10-Mar-24 12:44 AM] archielvahr#0000
Oh a few notes, those are the fields right out of FIO. They are a little buggy for users who have recycled CO names. And the creation date from FIO is wrong for people who have COLIQ'd or have a reused company code. Unfortunately there's no easy fix for that on the fio side. 

I also hand cleaned up old members, so if anyone is missing that's me just messing up some data.


[10-Mar-24 12:44 AM] archielvahr#0000
I had started listing planet data esp for the messed up accounts but it was too much work so I stopped


[10-Mar-24 12:44 AM] archielvahr#0000
the last column is the number of days active reported in the USR in-game buffer, which isn't in FIO yet.


[10-Mar-24 12:46 AM] archielvahr#0000
The original rule of OOG was to leave the corp if you went inactive to prevent dilution of dividends on people who won't use them.. but it's tough to stay on top of that.

BL  | b * 1 | 33-48 |   610 |   20k-29k |
HSE | b * 1 | 33-48 |  1000 |   33k-48k |
AEF | a / 3 |   174 |   400 |       70k |
INS | a *10 |  5000 |    22 |      110k |
TSH | b * 1 | 33-48 |  3700 | 122k-177k |

I've been neglecting some recruitment guidelines and I've also been thinking of putting up a public post. I do want to stay on top of the inevitable churn


[17-Apr-24 11:40 AM] archielvahr#0000
Recruitment Spiel:

We are the premier corporation in Antares space and the largest governance organization in the universe. As a corporation, we work to ensure the stability of the Antares region, as well as creating a fun and engaging place for our members to enjoy Prosperous Universe. Our corporation includes weekly dividends in excess of 200k AIC, governance training and support, planetary and regional development, a discord-based internal auction/order system and preferential material access and prices. The Bank of OOG offers loans, currency conversion, and investment opportunities, including base teleports. Our friendly group has members that are active in all timezones.

Recruitment Guidelines:

OOG is a highly selective corp with limited available positions. We're looking for members who:

* Interested in being a team player and being active in the corp and community
* Are primarily based in ANT space
* Have a Pro License and plan to maintain it
* Bonus: Interest in planetary governance, or are already a governor.

------------------

How we internally evaluate candidates on those guidelines:

* 30 Days of overall game experience
* Current Pro License and plans to maintain it
* 80% of bases in Antares sphere of influence
* The ability to communicate in English
* A team player attitude 
* Active in other PRUN discords

Nice to have:
* Decent growth to company age ratio
* They have an interest in governance.
* They have cool side projects (maintain tools, run in-game development projects, well known to the community, etc)
* They're already a governor somewhere.

[25-Apr-24 01:29 PM] archielvahr#0000
We used to sell ready-to-assemble ships, but moved to individually putting stuff on the CX so anyone could assemble their own ships (with their own clicks). But I've begun to suspect that there are people who have money and want ships, but don't want to mess around with individually buying components from the CX, even when they are usually all in stock.


[25-Apr-24 01:30 PM] archielvahr#0000
I think the complexity is a turn off for some people - too many ship options, too many things to buy, not obviously clear they are all available unless you check all the order books.

[26-Apr-24 02:05 PM] archielvahr#0000
Here's my draft of prices. My thought is that I'll pay these rates to buy components in bulk, in the appropriate ratios, then I'll sell them externally at the 5.98m AIC price. I tried to aim high on prices, taking either the higher of the CX price or the GTU price, with some adjustments for the larger differences, and the internal prod price. I wanted to hold it under 6m. But I could be talked out of that. 

So is anyone unhappy with any of these prices? 

125    1x MFL
150    1x MSL
390    2x LFE
180    2x MFE
60    1x SFE
240    94x LHP
55    128x SSC
420    1x LCB
750    1x FSE
700    1x QCR
1300    1x CQM
1100    1x BR1
350    1x FFC    
160    1x Assembly Fee

Ship cost: 5.98m AIC


[26-Apr-24 02:07 PM] churavis#0000
I fear that absolute prices like this will limit your ability to adjust package sell prices based on market conditions or individual negotiations


[26-Apr-24 02:09 PM] churavis#0000
What if it doesn't sell and you want to lower prices, or it's super popular and you need to raise prices?


[26-Apr-24 02:16 PM] archielvahr#0000
Yeah that's a good question. Maybe these will be considered flexible first-round prices. I do want to sell from stock that I actually have so I can fulfill them immediately, rather than a "build-to-order" system, where I have to track pending orders and deal with a backlog.


[26-Apr-24 02:17 PM] archielvahr#0000
I'm thinking this is a no-backlog, first come first serve, maximum FOMO, minimum bookkeeping situation.

[26-Apr-24 06:16 PM] hernanduer#0000

[26-Apr-24 06:16 PM] hernanduer#0000
the second is what I kind of wanted to do for my own production sheets, but I ended up forgetting a lot


[26-Apr-24 06:17 PM] hernanduer#0000
so make TIO? Okay, cost of PIO+EXT degradation + 5%


[26-Apr-24 06:17 PM] hernanduer#0000
TIO -> TI? TIO cost + PIO+SME degradation + 5%


[26-Apr-24 06:17 PM] hernanduer#0000
you could make a whole sheet using just market input consumables


[26-Apr-24 06:18 PM] hernanduer#0000
then assume all products (non-consumable) are made in-house and follow that staged profit


[26-Apr-24 06:19 PM] hernanduer#0000
we could use a basis like that for creating suggested "corp" prices


[26-Apr-24 06:19 PM] hernanduer#0000
doesn't account for opportunity loss against current market conditions though, so it's at the player's discretion whether they use the suggested price


[26-Apr-24 06:21 PM] archielvahr#0000
I did make one of those once, but it's got so many caveats that it ended up beingt not too useful (except maybe as a gauge of MM prices, which was sort of the intent). Google sheets was kind of choking on the iterative calculations since I recalculate the price of DW based on the price of the consumables needed to make it, (DW, RAT, COF, Bfabs for EXTs, mats for the FPs, etc). Did the whole thing (except transport costs and taxes).


[26-Apr-24 06:21 PM] archielvahr#0000
And assumed all the materials were extracted from a certain typical but "good" planet.


[26-Apr-24 06:22 PM] hernanduer#0000
yeah that's why you'd have to have some baseline, I was saying consumables but could be any 1 resource


[26-Apr-24 06:22 PM] archielvahr#0000

[26-Apr-24 06:22 PM] archielvahr#0000
just like newton's method


[26-Apr-24 06:23 PM] hernanduer#0000

[28-Apr-24 11:19 AM] hernanduer#0000
max power on the QCR is about 20% less than max power on the RCT, so at max power it should be around 20% faster. The reason for the 2.4ps requirement is because of the wind up time, QCRs wind up a lot faster


[28-Apr-24 11:20 AM] hernanduer#0000
and if you don't put power above 80% on the RCT, then their speeds will be roughly equivalent from that point on a fuel-to-fuel basis (100% of QCR spends the same amount of fuel as 80% on an RCT, and thus travels at the same speed - sans the wind up time which is a constant and much faster with the QCR)

[06-May-24 10:37 AM] archielvahr#0000
They announced some changes to hull plates and shields


[06-May-24 10:37 AM] archielvahr#0000
Other hull plates will get lighter and might get good. Shield reduce your need for hull plates now too


[06-May-24 10:41 AM] archielvahr#0000
```Namely, we will reduce the weight of higher-level hull plates, so they will mainly differ in production cost (and of course their resistance). Basic and lightweight plates will be adjusted as well, but this should make the more expensive ones more viable in comparison. Shield recipes will become less expensive overall as well. On top of that, applying shields to your ship will reduce the amount of hull plate materials you have to provide. The more and higher-tier shields your ship blueprint has, the more hull plates will be deducted from your repair bill, so shields will not just reduce the rate of deterioration but also save on other required repair materials. This should make using (especially higher-tier) shields more of an actually viable choice.```

It only increases inflation if you use it to buy something. Money that is thrown into the ARC money pire or that sits in your account won't affect inflation.

[04-Jun-24 06:45 PM] tuffyless#0000
Sanity check plz regarding the CoGM in PRUNplanner ...

If I set all the CoG's Empire-Wide that I produce, as the BUY price, to match my own cost of production 
(*which includes running through all the reiterations as many times as needed, since lowering consumables for example, lowers the CoGM of other products*), 
actually result in a true actual cost of production?  

Minus taxes & transportation of course.


[04-Jun-24 06:49 PM] tuffyless#0000
--
Sorry if that's just a string of text making no sense, it's kinda tough to ask the question.

Example RAT was for like 10 or 15 AIC something to produce.

It just didnt seem right so I clicked the delete all button and havent retried it again.  
Takes alot time to reiterate through all the chains to get to the bottom line.


[04-Jun-24 06:58 PM] sidepipe#0000
That seems like it could be about right


[04-Jun-24 06:59 PM] sidepipe#0000
I‚Äôve been meaning to do something similar - I make my own RAT, which I grow the plants for, which I extract the water for, which I make the bfabs for


[04-Jun-24 07:00 PM] sidepipe#0000
So assuming you are able to make all you consume, the cogm should be pretty low


[04-Jun-24 07:02 PM] tuffyless#0000
Exactly!  Same here.

I make nearly 100% of my own inputs from, bottom to top, for the final products which I produce.

And when reiterating through all those chains over and over resetting the updated BUY price accordingly, the ending CoGM is pretty damn low.


[04-Jun-24 07:04 PM] tuffyless#0000
So low in fact I couldnt believe it lol.  
thanks for the sanity Sidepipe.  üôÇ  
Will redo it all again when bored.


[04-Jun-24 07:05 PM] sidepipe#0000
Upside - huge profit margins on the stuff you do sell! Downside - you eat up a ton of your own stuff and can't sell it üòÑ


[04-Jun-24 07:08 PM] tuffyless#0000
Agree!  
Maybe another sanity check I think it leads to an inflated Empire-Wide profit/loss margin.  

By that I mean, I think all the inputs you consume yourself, from all the various planets you produce them on, need to have SELL's matching your own BUY prices.

Otherwise, PRUNplanner thinks you're SELLing your own inputs at CX prices and BUYing your inputs from discounted genie.


[04-Jun-24 07:08 PM] sidepipe#0000
Yeah, that's why I have one CX preference set to Buy = Sell = AVG

{Reactions}
üëç 

[04-Jun-24 07:09 PM] archielvahr#0000
I did make a sheet to calculate the same thing, and yes the prices can get extremely low. Extracted goods are something to think about. I made a sheet to extract them at like the 90th percentile efficiency- compared to what planets actually exist with those resources on them. 

A few notes. I think that if you are totally operating on "cost to produce", the prices get o low that taxes might be a non-trivial added cost. I ignored them but probably shouldn't. Maybe likewise for travel costs.


[04-Jun-24 07:09 PM] sidepipe#0000
yeah, I think taxes and transport cost would actually be a  lower bound


[04-Jun-24 07:10 PM] tuffyless#0000

Ex: 
You're making MEA.
Taxes on the H2O.  on the Agri.  on the RAT.  on the FIM.  on the MEA.  etc
